Remember the 2010 to 2012 Mustang? How the tail light redesign alienated people? How aftermarket companies have plugs to delete the weird lower "V" shaped bottom? Not a fan of the new pinched tail light look. Its awful from every angle. Triple headlights? Unnecessary, but I can give that a mild pass. The interior? Well, the classic mustang "double hump" dashboard is gone and destroyed ...replaced by a luxury sedan wide screen TV. It's not an improvement. Completely ruins the feel, now it's quite frankly any brands bland sedan.  There are certain design elements that tie an iconic brand together. The new dashboard design has lost any recognizable Mustang cues. Idea: Turn the centre console to the vertical, and let that be your infotainment centre. Leave the digital speed and tach in place from the outgoing model. I get the feeling that whoever signed off on these design changes...has no tie to the Mustang's history. I just want to rip out the dashboard and replace it with the outgoing models design....it really is that bad. *waiting for the redesign in three...two...*  *sigh* - You had ONE job Ford... 5 out of 10.

This new S650 is attractive but aggressive front to rear. The interior has finally been brought into the 21st century with amazing gauges and infotainment center along with a better overall design with the addition of soft touch materials. Even a drift brake developed by pro drifter Vaughn Gitten was added for those into drifting. The new dual throttle body Gen 4 Coyote should be a great addition. I noticed on the tach the redline was 7500 RPMs, plus a dual Ram Air system that runs to each side of the front grill. Even the new EcoBoost has added a electronic turbo and I'm guessing similar horsepower as the current HPP offers. Also kudos to Ford for teaming up with Multimatic for creating their new GT3 factory race team. It's possible with class changes in IMSA. The new GT3 S650 might compete against the C8 Z06. Ford will also offer the GT4 S650 and the new NHRA X class drag racing Mustang for Privateer racers. Thanks to Ford for keeping the V8 alive and well. There's even rumors the Shelby GT500 will continue through model year 2024 as an S550. Disappearing for one year in model year 2025 while reappearing as an S650 for model year 2026. Great review in the fantastic S650 Mustang GT performance.

My 2021 Bronco has the 8 in screen, and it works decently. Apple carplay has been the weak link when it comes to the reliability of it all. I just know that down the road electronics in cars will be the death of so many cars. Ford has a really bad quality control issue on their electronics so Im sick of them stuffing their cars with these when I know they wont be high quality.

I'm surprised you didn't mention some "quirks and features". The new Mustang displays are actually based on "Unreal" graphics, a 3D rendering company that a lot of high end realistic video games are based on. That's pretty cool for us tech geeks. The Brembo brakes can be optioned with different colors and badges. The seat belts can also be optioned with different colors. The new 5.0 will come with dual throttle botties. Each throttle body has separate ducts going to the front grills, similar to a "ram" air intake.  The new 2.3 Eco boost now has an electronic VGT turbo. Also, for me, the remote revs would be useful for testing different exhaust or mufflers without needing someone in the car to blip the throttle.

Some goods and bads here. The car sounds great, and I love the exhaust note options and the configurable gauge screen layouts, although I must say I prefer analog gauges in a muscle car, and not really screens. Exterior-wise, I don't think the car looks better than the previous generation. In fact, I find it a bit awkward looking and not as well proportioned. The wheels look too small for the body. The front end looks cheap with all of that black plastic, and the headlights look like they came off of an Acura. Not a good look for a Mustang.
I'm sure it will have the get up and go as the Mustang power trains have been really good, and I love that there is a six speed manual. But I think the styling has gone awry.

I love the angles on the side of the body by the back wheel. It looks very chiseled and muscular. The sharper hood line also looks awesome to that effect. The front looks great, a respectful and modern evolution of the previous model. The back of the car looks very interesting. There is a whopping and unapologetic crease.

The interior has broken the bounds of the low quality that typically limits American muscle cars. Huge win. I'm kinda picky, but I would appreciate if they had an interior tier where you can buy OLED screens and/or a faster processor for the OS... would really seal the deal there, but that may require unreasonable effort to develop. Who knows how difficult it is to implement that somewhat new technology, with screen burnout (though perhaps replaceable), the logistical issues of producing and offering more options, and other problems.

Bigger, better engines are as expected üòÅ Sounds awesome!  A stronger and tighter rev, yet still characteristically Mustang rumble as the engine slows down. And with the improvement in handling from the 5th to the 6th generation in mind, we should have some great things to expect from this generation. I hope Ford offers a traditional gauge cluster, for collectors who don't want the driving experience tied to tech that will soon look dated.   Also think they should have kept the dual-cowl and gone with a narrower vertical screen in the center console instead.   Thankful they didn't go all-capacitive buttons like VW did with the disastrous new Golf R.   I do wish they'd kept minimal physical climate controls, perhaps just small left/right dials that showed temperature, and you could push them in to bring up an on-screen menu for more settings.   It's OK for the output to be on a big screen, but the input should be via tactile buttons that you can find and use without looking.

I find the different philosophies that companies have about digital displays interesting.  IMO, you want some that looks good, but timeless, with a crisp image and responsive menus because this car is going to be driver by someone for the next 20+ years and that display needs to hold up if you're going to justify having it.  Ford does exactly this, I think, and others cars with cheaper displays will feel even cheaper in the future and loss more value in the second hand market as a result.

Well first and foremost I'm extremely disappointed that Doug didn't get in the back seats...‚òπÔ∏è
But aside from that I really like the body of this new Mustang. I've owned a couple Camaros and I've never owned a Mustang although we've had a couple in my family and so I like both Camaros and Mustangs. However I have been disappointed with the last couple generations of Camaros because of the poor visibility and unnecessary high non-erodynamic front end.  But I've been disappointed with Mustang this last generation because you couldn't get a sunroof and it's so cheesy to pump in fake engine sound through the speakers. As far as Motors are concerned I've had a few LS Motors and I've had a few 5.0 coyotes in my F-150s and both are excellent Motors although I'm a little partial to the older 5.7 LS engines and the 5.0 Coyote engine because they get better fuel mileage than the 6.2 L. And I know people will be like who cares about fuel mileage, but I like to cruise in the low triple digits for extended periods which is why I like these cars because they're excellent sport touring cars and at those speeds better aerodynamics and a more fuel efficient motor makes the experience more enjoyable so you're not hunting for a gas station every couple hundred miles. Anyway this is a really beautiful looking mustang, love the body, I hope they put in a sunroof, I could do without the rear wing because again for the reason I buy these cars it will just cut into fuel mileage, and I like the screens but I do wish they were a little more integrated looking. Anyway, well done!

Best Mustang review out there right now, that's why Doug makes the big bucks. I gotta say, although I've never been a Mustang fan- too big and heavy for me, It's very obvious American car manufacturers like Ford and GM know their customers. The little details they add are fantastic and custom tailored to a specific person. For example; all Corvettes have always been able to easily carry two sets of golf clubs in the trunk, Porsche cannot. Just as many Porsche owners golf but they leave this feature out and charge double. This Ford comes with a manual as STANDARD, the Toyota Supra left that out until 2023 and it's a rare option. In conclusion, sometimes these foreign companies just make stupid decisions on a large scale (no Yaris in North America, new Acura Integra, etc) and Ford and GM look like marketing geniuses (Bronco, C8 Z06, Gladiator, etc). Did Europe and Japan just stop thinking entirely? Ford made only minor changes to the Mustang because it sells like crazy, revolutionary design is a historical risk for this model, (GM knew it was the only place left to go with Corvette) they know that. This new one will sell out. It's nice to see US companies still consumer friendly, it's so rare these days.

I just bought a 2020 Mustang this year and have enjoyed it tremendously so far. I'll make this comment now to see how I feel about it several years from now and see how the new car ages, but for starters the gauge cluster is not appealing at all to the one I have now. The "tablet" look that most cars are having where the infotainment displays aren't "built-in" to the dashboards does not look appealing, but rather an afterthought. Aside from that, the display itself has a lot of empty space and seems too much for having too little. Everything is crammed in to one location with the corners or outside areas exposed with nothing. It could've been consolidated to seem more appealing but alas we'll see. The one thing I notice with my display is everything seems to be well filled out, nothing hard to find or see, with both important information wrapping around the screen and secondary information located elsewhere. 

Interested to see how the GT500 is developed from this, as well as if we're getting a GT350. Hopefully ford goes out with a bang on both of these models and includes one with an optional Terminator engine option.

I'm not a big fan of the dashboard "humps" being removed, or the side scoops and lines that have been a staple of the Mustang for decades. But even with that being said, and as much as I'll miss those features, I frankly like this design more than anything I've seen from the model since the outgoing 2004 versions, which I still own. Despite the missing  profile details on the exterior, this is the meanest, beefiest design I think I've ever seen on a Mustang, and I love it, especially the front end and the angular taillight panels. 

The interior....well, the missing scoops are a bummer, and I'm still not used to cars being dominated by screens, but overall, it's a great looking interior I think. And the main thing is it just doesn't look as plasticky and cheap as older models did. My aforementioned 2004 GT, as much as I love it, has the cheapest most outdated interior imaginable even by 2004 standards, so I love what I'm seeing here. This is a beautiful car.
No electric powertrain, naturally aspirated and with manual as standard, as God intended.

A comment about startup sound.  Most cars have a catalyst heat mode for a period of time (10 or 20 seconds) after a cold start.  This mode typically retards the ignition and advances the exhaust cam to "blowtorch" the catalyst.  These things also create a louder sound during this period.

I definitely think the angles are way to sharp compared to the older model. The rear taillight bend feels unnatural, and the giant front grill is a little ridiculous. The headlights are some sort of weird mashup between the 2015 design and Mach-E headlights, which I don‚Äôt think is as good as the previous generations gill like tri bar headlights. The interior is honestly just ugly. The middle of the steering wheel looks like it was chiseled out of a rock, and the large screens are just an eyesore, and the air vents are moved to a way less convenient place then the previous generation. The fox body style gauges and the drift mode are pretty cool, but the loss of physical gauges is an L. I know people put a lot of work into this design, but it looks like they threw the old S550 into photoshop, maxed out the sharpness level and called it a day. I guess I have an unpopular opinion, even though I'm a die-hard Mustang fan, to me it is a very cool Muscle Car, but not so much of a cool Mustang. It looks like the team responsible for it is just a project group from highschool that forgot that they had to turn in their group homework and just rushed something out : the design just look like a caricature of the outgoing model, you even lose the round headlight design, and the classic double cockpit design (because of course it's easier to just throw an ugly and giant iPad in there), just throw better quality plastics, cool badges, 10 more hp and voil√†, let's call it a 7th gen. I'm glad this car still exists and that it still has a V8 in 2022 (or 2024) but given that they had 10 years to develop it after the release of the 6th gen, it just look plain lazy. And that front fascia looks ridiculous, all squares, all grill, with a face only a mother could love. At least it sounds very good from the factory. It looks like a very good car, but I'm not sure it's worth the ton of extra cash they'll try to squeeze out of people compared to the outgoing model or a nice optioned phase 1 S550. And what is that "Dark horse" thing ? Sounds very tacky. It looks like all the marketing naming around that car has been handled by kids. The electric Charger is a tacky thing but at least they got the design right, bold and daring.
